column4: hello. Is there a way to play a Video-CD that is just mounted from an ISO-image (not a real CD)?
via vlc sure
But how? I can't use the vlc-device and I don't know how else I should start the video-CD or which file(s) I should choose in vlc.
right click open with vlc
Thanks, I will try that.
since PPA are disabled on version upgrade, you'd need to re-enable them if a higher compatible version exists
some PPA *might* work with a difference in version, though that would be risky and depend on the nature of the PPA
> Mrokii, since PPA are disabled on version upgrade, you'd need to re-enable them if a higher compatible version exists
thats correct, was there some question about that?
thats what is necessary to the best of my knowledge, as the ubuntu system wont check it for you
I'm not talking about re-enabling as such. As it stands at the moment, I have to visit each of the PPAs and check if they have updated the source to 12.04
it would complain if the version was causing problems, thats about it
I think he missed the context of your question
thats app armor
oops, yes, "app armor". But what is this about?
yes. there is an arrow that leads to a menu saying, dont ask again
Hm, okay. Didn't notice that yet, but I will look. Thanks.
I have no clue what you're talking about, honestly. Was that a remark about me asking the question once more or an actual answer? If so, I don't see anything like what you described.
a small popup window that appears in the address bar of Firefox? I thought that was your issue

Yes, but not only in Firefox. And it has four options, Open in Mozilla, Open in Firefox, Open in Opera (I think) and something else I forgot. That's all. Strange thing is it doesn't always appear and I don't know how to either disable it or change the (for me) useless options.
that sounds somewhat different on second listening as you have further clarified
Sorry for not explaining it properly. I just don't get where this is coming from, but as it's not only FX where it appeard (Thunderbird and Chrome as well) I assume it must be some Ubuntu-thing.
